quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 5 Session 2
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 5 Session 2
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 2) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-20
entry.itemBody: When a company has significant intangibles, asset-based valuation is most likely:

answerFeedback.6991c9cc-d830-400e-ad26-d7a39d574dbb: Correct because when a company has significant intangibles, the analyst should prefer a forward-looking cash flow valuation.
answerFeedback.e897979c-3129-488b-8644-859c773bfece: Incorrect because an asset-based valuation of a company uses estimates of the market or fair value of the company’s assets and liabilities. Thus, asset-based valuations work well for companies that do not have a high proportion of intangible or “off the books” assets.
answerFeedback.fbfc4cdf-ed38-42a3-897f-fcea840fec8b: Incorrect because asset-based valuation may not consider some intangibles, thus it can give a “floor” value, not a maximum value, for a situation involving a significant amount of intangibles.

choices.itemBody: A. used to determine the value of off the books assets.
B. less preferred than forward-looking cash flow valuation.
C. appropriate to calculate a maximum value for the company.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08755
entry.itemBody: The lead underwriter in an IPO most likely:

answerFeedback.3a8a415d-0ede-4b83-a51f-2acddfc80dcd: Incorrect because in the case of an IPO, the underwriter usually also promises to make a market in the security for about a month to ensure that the secondary market will be liquid and to provide price support, if necessary.
answerFeedback.90e6de11-9217-4c6b-8303-6da9ee3cbdc2: Correct because the lead underwriter is the book builder for the offering. Book building is a process where the investment bank then lines up subscribers who will buy the security. For large issues, a syndicate of investment banks and broker-dealers helps the lead underwriter build the book.
answerFeedback.dd3f560c-4516-4d94-9dfa-893d8d4d40da: Incorrect because investment banks often support their book building by providing investment information and opinion about the issuer to their clients and to the public.

choices.itemBody: A. acts as the book builder for the offering.
B. is not responsible for making a market in the securities.
C. is prohibited from providing an opinion about the issue to their clients.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Agarwal-03
entry.itemBody: The value of a European put option is directly related to the:

answerFeedback.0bbb7330-e8d3-4a9d-9055-62f41b130f82: Incorrect because the value of a European put option is inversely related to the value of the underlying.
answerFeedback.31cc880a-3913-4f3c-b5b6-9df1f48a72ba: Correct because the value of a European put is directly related to the volatility of the underlying.
answerFeedback.85e6cf17-186f-4340-8092-3df074d2bbe2: Incorrect because the value of a European put is inversely related to the risk-free interest rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01681
entry.itemBody: If it is difficult to find a buyer or a seller for an asset, the asset most likely trades on:

answerFeedback.5d61a9b4-bc5a-44a3-ae2d-cf942a22af21: Incorrect because dealers generally are unable or unwilling to hold these assets in their inventories, they will not make markets in them.
answerFeedback.ad39a5a4-01a6-4d46-bbae-b90f7ce1d4b9: Correct because brokered markets are markets in which brokers arrange trades among their clients. Brokers organize markets for instruments for which finding a buyer or seller willing to trade is difficult because the instruments are unique.
answerFeedback.ffc76601-c47b-48e3-9b79-db86c916836f: Incorrect because organizing order-driven markets for these instruments (assets for which finding a buyer or seller is difficult) is not sensible because too few traders would submit orders for them.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Huffman-05
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a consequence of the overconfidence bias? An investor who:

answerFeedback.9240a220-f145-4d81-8b5a-092de0480e5e: Incorrect because as a result of overconfidence bias investors may overestimate, not underestimate, expected returns.
answerFeedback.d5a33cfa-8857-4795-bd64-bb488b447359: Correct because as a result of overconfidence bias, investors may underestimate risks and overestimate expected returns and/or hold poorly diversified portfolios, which may result in significant downside risk.
answerFeedback.e160243d-111e-4f61-ad08-01d45e53ceda: Incorrect because as a result of overconfidence bias, investors may underestimate, not overestimate, downside risks.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lamba-05
entry.itemBody: Forward contracts are different from futures contracts because forwards are:

answerFeedback.34c1ce5b-6357-4dfc-b5fc-8c89377e9c6b: Incorrect because unlike futures contracts, forward contracts are not standardized.
answerFeedback.5e9aca61-bdd4-4559-89a2-bf463f846c71: Correct because futures contracts differ from forward contracts in that they have standard terms, and are traded on a futures exchange, whereas forward contracts are traded over-the-counter.
answerFeedback.dbf27aa9-af6a-4e4f-80fe-9753577ad5c0: Incorrect because forward contracts are not marked to market like futures contracts.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Huffman-03
entry.itemBody: The market model is most likely used to predict:

answerFeedback.7bc5edcc-e139-49d5-97d8-778be1f1f014: Incorrect because the intercept, αi, and slope coefficient, βi, of the market model can be estimated by using historical security and market returns. These parameter estimates are then used to predict company-specific returns that a security may earn in a future period.
answerFeedback.e7c2c230-cfe9-4ae8-a3e4-40d878065bbb: Correct because the intercept, αi, and slope coefficient, βi, of the market model can be estimated by using historical security and market returns. These parameter estimates are then used to predict company-specific returns that a security may earn in a future period.
answerFeedback.ee9a619b-baed-4f0b-a8f0-f2124972afc8: Incorrect because the market model is a return generating model which can be used to predict company-specific returns based on market returns. Macroeconomic factor models (not the market model) use economic factors that are correlated with security returns. These factors may include economic growth.

choices.itemBody: A. market returns in a future period.
B. economic growth in a future period.
C. company-specific returns in a future period.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Tomter-04
entry.itemBody: Which of the following ESG investment approaches best describes positive screening?

answerFeedback.3ef017eb-baef-42d8-824c-731e3bc68084: Incorrect because it describes impact investing, not ESG integration. Impact investing is defined as investments made with the intention to generate positive, measurable social and environmental impact alongside a financial return.
answerFeedback.c0a50077-52ce-4237-b10b-821014864900: Correct because positive screening is defined as including sectors or companies based on specific ESG criteria, typically ESG performance relative to industry peers.
answerFeedback.d9f7be5c-21d4-450b-b207-3c148ab020fa: Incorrect because this describes ESG integration, not positive screening. ESG integration is defined as the systematic consideration of material ESG factors in asset allocation, security selection, and portfolio construction decisions.

choices.itemBody: A. Systematic consideration of material ESG factors in asset allocation
B. Inclusion of sectors or companies in the portfolio based on specific ESG criteria
C. Investments made with the intention to generate positive, measurable social and environmental impact

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Y.Zhang-05
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely undertaken during the risk budgeting process?

answerFeedback.46c6d2e6-8242-47fc-887a-c39283e98e8e: Correct because risk budgeting quantifies and allocates the tolerable risk by specific metrics. Four well-known single-dimension measures that are often used are standard deviation, beta, value at risk (VaR), and scenario loss.
answerFeedback.c9710e83-f241-433a-b135-9dc8df6fccd1: Incorrect because it describes risk tolerance, not risk budgeting. Risk tolerance identifies the extent to which the organization is willing to experience losses or opportunity costs and to fail in meeting its objectives. Whereas risk tolerance focuses on the appetite for risk and what is and is not acceptable, risk budgeting has a more specific focus on how that risk is taken.
answerFeedback.ea090c19-c6a1-4a22-801e-efd797651fc9: Incorrect because it describes self-insurance, an example of risk acceptance, not risk budgeting. Self-insurance is the notion of bearing a risk that is considered undesirable but too costly to eliminate by external means. It may involve the establishment of a reserve to cover losses.

choices.itemBody: B. Setting a limit for value at risk (VaR)
C. Establishing a reserve to cover potential future losses

entry.title: ITEM_20190531015
entry.itemBody: An 8-year, 3.5% annual coupon bond is priced at 92.1492, with a yield to maturity of 4.7% and a Macaulay duration of 7.0705. If rates decrease by 75 bps, the percentage price change of the bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.41ed4a36-252a-4787-8cb4-bcbb0c6b0e26: Incorrect because yields and bond prices are inversely related, the price change should be positive. Also, Macaulay duration, rather than modified duration, was used in the price change formula: 7.0705 x (–0.0075) = –0.05303 ≈ –5.3%.
answerFeedback.46a781aa-70cf-4fcd-a79c-029b26075f35: Incorrect because the price change is incorrectly calculated by using Macaulay duration, rather than modified duration. –7.0705 x (–0.0075) = –0.05303 ≈ 5.3%.
answerFeedback.a6c8312d-fd48-4368-bd49-4ca81ff90892:
Correct because to determine the percentage price change of a bond for a given change in yield, first convert Macaulay duration (7.0705) to modified duration by dividing Macaulay duration by 1 plus yield per period.

ModDur = 7.0705 1.047 =6.7531

Next, multiply annual modified duration by the change in yield.

%Δ PV Full ≈−6.7531×( −0.0075 )=0.0507

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Mazur-24
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company (in $ thousands):

  Year 1 Year 2
Operating income  255 234
Depreciation and amortization 432 677
Interest expense 170 156

Based on the interest coverage ratio using EBITDA, the company's creditworthiness has:

answerFeedback.a2071610-fca7-4195-b798-938a30ebf7ff:
Correct because over the period the interest coverage ratio increased, which indicates that the company is better positioned to service its debt. A higher ratio indicates higher credit quality.

Interest coverage ratio is calculated as EBITDA/Interest expense and EBITDA = Operating income + Depreciation and amortization, hence the ratios are:

Year 1: EBITDA: 255 + 432 = 687 ⇒ Interest coverage: 687/170 = 4.04 ≈ 4.0x; 

Year 2: EBITDA: 234 + 677 = 911 ⇒ Interest coverage: 911/156 = 5.84 ≈ 5.8x.
answerFeedback.c23fbeee-6c4d-47e1-b672-4b2a3748032e: Incorrect because over the period the interest coverage ratio increased and a higher ratio indicates higher, not lower, credit quality.
answerFeedback.ea738d3e-92b6-43d5-b25b-10df5c8eb6a3:
Incorrect because EBIT (i.e., operating income) is used instead of EBITDA to calculate the interest coverage ratio. If the interest coverage ratio is calculated as EBIT/Interest expense, the ratios are:

Year 1: 255/170 = 1.5x; 

Year 2: 234/156 = 1.5x.

This stable ratio would imply no change to the company's creditworthiness.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606015
entry.itemBody:
A correlation matrix of the returns for securities A, B, and C is reported below:

Security A B C
A 1 --- ---
B 0.5 1 ---
C 0 -0.5 1
Assuming that the expected return and the standard deviation of each security are the same, a portfolio consisting of an equal allocation of which two securities will be most effective for portfolio diversification?

answerFeedback.05e34af2-acdb-4df4-b876-c57f2992ef72: Incorrect. The neutral correlation of 0.0 between investment securities A and B means that these instruments have no correlation with each other. While portfolio A and B is superior to portfolio A and C, it is not superior to the negative correlation of portfolio B and C.
answerFeedback.31927f38-e44a-4601-9088-50c0326aa84b: Correct. The negative correlation of –0.5 between investment securities B and C is the lowest and thus is the most effective for portfolio diversification.
answerFeedback.5803c02f-29e6-4540-871d-f45a797f07a5: Incorrect. The positive correlation of 0.5 between investment securities A and C means that these instruments have positive correlation with each other and are not effective for portfolio diversification.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Larrabee-02
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a putable bond currently trading at par:

Price per 100 of Par Value Change in Benchmark Yield
102.25 –25 bps
100.00 Unchanged
99.25 +25 bps

The effective duration of this bond is:

answerFeedback.06aaa9d4-a4f2-4d5a-a10f-f6d04df1a8ce:
Incorrect because only the increase in price is used:

EffDur ≠ ((PV–)(PV0)) / (2 * (ΔCurve) * PV0)

= (102.25 – 100.00) / (2 * 0.0025 * 100.00)

= 2.25 / (0.005 * 100) = 4.5
answerFeedback.91b1f6be-5af7-436d-8952-4d7660d5e1bb:
Correct because effective duration is calculated as follows:

EffDur = ((PV–)(PV+)) / (2 * (ΔCurve) * PV0)

= (102.25 – 99.25) / (2 * 0.0025 * 100.00)

= 3 / (0.005 * 100) = 6.0
answerFeedback.d7f8559b-a200-4004-b71b-20113b207aa9:
Incorrect because only the upward shift in the yield curve is used:

EffDur ≠ ((PV0)(PV+)) / (2 * (ΔCurve) * PV0)

= (100.00 – 99.25) / (2 * 0.0025 * 100.00)

= 0.75 / (0.005 * 100) = 1.5

entry.title: ITEM_20170427062
entry.itemBody: A private equity firm sells a portfolio company to a buyer that is active in the same industry as the portfolio company. This transaction is best described as a(n):

answerFeedback.3dcadf14-557c-4e2d-95e1-c23d8353fb7b: Correct because in a trade sale, a portion or a division of the private company is sold either via direct sale or auction to a strategic buyer interested in increasing the scale and scope of the existing business.
answerFeedback.4a4a5e3b-cbb4-4e81-a1cd-f3524ca3666d: Incorrect because this approach represents a sale of the company to another private equity firm or group of financial buyers.
answerFeedback.a34f36aa-1e8a-4ee1-b3e1-c89ff43f7569: Incorrect because an initial public offering involves the sale of shares to public investors. Public listing on an exchange can take place either as an initial public offering (IPO), a direct listing, or a special acquisition company (SPAC). IPOs are the most common means of raising capital in public equity markets using financial intermediaries to underwrite the offering. When a private equity firm or company founder takes a company public, the portfolio company sells its shares, including some or all of those held by the private equity firm, to public investors.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-18
entry.itemBody: Key rate duration:

answerFeedback.42c208d6-a1ef-4005-bbba-453a9ff10a51: Correct because a key rate duration (or partial duration) is a measure of a bond’s sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield at a specific maturity.
answerFeedback.493ee51e-c092-48ef-9df2-aee39e26271a: Incorrect because key rate duration assumes non-parallel shifts in the benchmark yield curve. Key rate duration provides insight into a bond’s sensitivity to non-parallel benchmark yield curve changes.
answerFeedback.c0db7b17-5b4c-4c9c-b8e9-2e863f569478: Incorrect because effective and key rate durations indicate the same sensitivity to interest rate changes when all yields change by the same amount. Effective duration measures a bond’s sensitivity to changes in the benchmark yield curve if all yields change by the same amount. Key rate duration provides further insight into a bond’s sensitivity to non-parallel benchmark yield curve changes. Key rate duration (or partial duration) is a measure of a bond’s sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield at a specific maturity. Key rate durations define a security’s price sensitivity over a set of maturities along the yield curve, with the sum of key rate durations being equal to the effective duration when yields are shifted by the same amount.

choices.itemBody: A. requires the shape of the benchmark yield curve to stay constant.
B. measures a bond's sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield at a specific maturity.
C. indicates the same interest rate sensitivity as effective duration for non-parallel shifts in the yield curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Vervloet-15
entry.itemBody: Which of the following natural resources has formed part of large institutional portfolios for decades?

answerFeedback.26eabb1f-c461-4b19-b272-87ec1ab2857b: Correct because timberland investment involves ownership of raw land and the harvesting of its trees for lumber, thus generating an income stream and the potential for capital gain, and timberland has been included in large institutional portfolios for decades. Farmland as an investment is a more recent phenomenon, with only a few dedicated funds involved. With population growth, weather, and water management becoming more topical, however, investors may turn to these assets to actively address sustainability.
answerFeedback.8542744f-6c41-4203-ad2f-a94907998a31: Incorrect because farmland as an investment is a more recent phenomenon, with only a few dedicated funds involved. With population growth, weather, and water management becoming more topical, however, investors may turn to these assets to actively address sustainability.
answerFeedback.a2ec82d0-406d-4d55-8b01-04650e2647b7: Incorrect because farmland as an investment is a more recent phenomenon, with only a few dedicated funds involved. With population growth, weather, and water management becoming more topical, however, investors may turn to these assets to actively address sustainability.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Agarwal-10
entry.itemBody: According to put-call parity, a long position in an underlying is equivalent to a long risk-free bond combined with a:

answerFeedback.25c0cec6-8cda-45b9-bda2-7993dea1c303: Incorrect because by using the symbols and the signs in these versions of put–call parity, we can see several important interpretations, including long asset = long call, short put, long bond. Long call, long put and long bond will not be equivalent to the long asset.
answerFeedback.6e08078e-b533-470d-86d2-8ad270930ea3: Incorrect because by using the symbols and the signs in these versions of put–call parity, we can see several important interpretations, including long asset = long call, short put, long bond. Short call, long put and long bond will not be equivalent to the long asset.
answerFeedback.7786ad1e-9864-48a5-a01f-2a74ae244310: Correct because by using the symbols and the signs in these versions of put–call parity, we can see several important interpretations, including long asset = long call, short put, long bond.

choices.itemBody: A. long call and a long put with the same strike.
B. long call and a short put with the same strike.
C. short call and a long put with the same strike.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Equity-Bangaruswamy-06
entry.itemBody: An investor values a company based on the dividend discount model. All else being equal, the estimated intrinsic value of the stock for a one-year holding period is most likely:

answerFeedback.207d4a2c-a5bd-410e-acf6-107fb3b381f9: Incorrect because the estimated intrinsic value of the stock for a one-year holding period will be the same as for a five-year holding period.
answerFeedback.5311df25-7b75-4dc1-b66e-6868d17c8077: Correct because the general form of the dividend discount model (DDM) applies even in the case in which the investor has a finite investment horizon. For that investor, stock value today depends directly on the dividends the investor expects to receive before the stock is sold and depends indirectly on the expected dividends for periods subsequent to that sale, because those expected future dividends determine the expected selling price. Therefore, the estimated intrinsic value of the stock for a one-year holding period will be the same as for a five-year holding period.
answerFeedback.a11144bf-7ae3-496d-8be7-0e08b1545a38: Incorrect because the estimated intrinsic value of the stock for a one-year holding period will be the same as for a five-year holding period.

choices.itemBody: A. lower than the estimated intrinsic value of the stock for a five-year holding period.
B. equal to the estimated intrinsic value of the stock for a five-year holding period.
C. higher than the estimated intrinsic value of the stock for a five-year holding period.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Erickson-14
entry.itemBody: Private real estate investors expect to generate the highest returns from:

answerFeedback.03558431-e127-4c57-b51b-b2cc37c5ead3: Incorrect because investors seeking higher returns than core strategies provide may also accept development, redevelopment, repositioning, and leasing risk. Finite-life closed-end funds are more commonly used for alpha- and beta-generating value-add and opportunistic investment styles. Value-add investments may require modest redevelopment or upgrades, the leasing of vacant space, or repositioning the underlying properties to earn a higher return than core properties. Opportunistic investments accept much higher risks than value-add or core strategies.
answerFeedback.73ebed9a-ec9f-44e4-bbe7-3654b984cadd: Incorrect because investors seeking higher returns may also accept development, redevelopment, repositioning, and leasing risk. Finite-life closed-end funds are more commonly used for alpha- and beta-generating value-add and opportunistic investment styles. Value-add investments may require modest redevelopment or upgrades, the leasing of vacant space, or repositioning the underlying properties to earn a higher return than core properties.
answerFeedback.b0f77476-1497-46c6-99fe-439d1aa23393: Correct because investors seeking higher returns may also accept development, redevelopment, repositioning, and leasing risk. Finite-life closed-end funds are more commonly used for alpha- and beta-generating value-add and opportunistic investment styles. Value-add investments may require modest redevelopment or upgrades, the leasing of vacant space, or repositioning the underlying properties to earn a higher return than core properties. Opportunistic investing accepts the much higher risks of development, major redevelopment, repurposing of assets, taking on large vacancies, and speculating on significant improvement in market conditions.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06711
entry.itemBody: An investor purchased a 5-year bond at issuance for 98 per 100 of par value and held the bond for two years. Coupon payments were reinvested at the original yield to maturity. If the realized horizon yield is equal to the original yield to maturity, the investor most likely sold the bond at a price:

answerFeedback.07b7ae18-b590-4b2d-b45a-3544feac3312: Incorrect because if the bond was sold at par, the horizon yield would be greater than the yield-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.6c57dd7c-8e0e-4b9c-a906-117bba04bdbb: Incorrect because if the bond was sold above par, the horizon yield would be greater than the yield-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.6dc960d1-ee49-4a3b-9688-6d28b61ab491: Correct because the realized horizon yield matches the original yield-to-maturity if (1) coupon payments are reinvested at the same interest rate as the original yield-to-maturity, and (2) the bond is sold at a price on the constant-yield price trajectory, which implies that the investor does not have any capital gains or losses when the bond is sold. Since the bond is sold prior to maturity, the bond would have to be sold at a price greater than 98 but less than 100.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09777
entry.itemBody: For portfolios composed of the risk-free asset and a risky asset, the expected return as a function of standard deviation of returns is graphically represented by the:

answerFeedback.136a2a86-9c59-4753-ab31-1e754795d5cf: Incorrect because the Markowitz efficient frontier is the curve that lies above and to the right of the global minimum-variance portfolio on the minimum-variance frontier, which in turn depicts portfolios with the minimum variance for a given return in a graph where the axes are standard deviation of returns and expected return. Thus, the Markowitz efficient frontier is a curve that contains many risky assets, and not the combinations of one risky asset with the risk-free asset.
answerFeedback.1b5e99e1-2613-4ef0-a130-0dacf2b03e71: Correct because a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset. The combination is called the capital allocation line.
answerFeedback.83637467-50aa-433a-bb09-6512e9d7812d: Incorrect because the security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, not standard deviation of returns, reflecting systematic risk, on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516145
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information about a company:
Most recent year’s dividend per share $1.47
Next year’s estimate of earnings per share $4.00
Estimate of long-run return on equity (ROE) 15%
Estimate of long-run dividend payout ratio 40%
Investors’ required rate of return 12%

The company’s justified forward P/E is closest to:

answerFeedback.2de3c8c7-d0f3-486c-820b-60532557bc33:
Correct because

Justified forward P/E: P0/E1 = p/(r – g)

p = Payout ratio = 40% (given); r = Required rate of return = 12% 

g = (1 – Dividend payout ratio) × ROE = (1 – 0.40) × 15 = 9%

P0/E1 = p/(r – g) = 0.40/(0.12 – 0.09) = 13.3×

Alternatively:

Justified forward P/E: P0/E1 = (D1/E1)/(r – g)

g = (1 – Dividend payout ratio) × ROE = (1 – 0.40) × 15 = 9%

D1 = $1.47 × 1.09 = 1.60; E1 = $4.00 (given); r = Required rate of return = 12% (given)

P0/E1 = (D1/E1)/(r – g) = (1.60/4.00)/(0.12 – 0.09) = 13.3
answerFeedback.6b438b3a-a7ed-4208-8328-6a0b91506725:
Incorrect because it uses retention ratio instead of payout ratio in the numerator.

P0/E1 = 0.60/(0.12 – 0.09) = 20
answerFeedback.90a5fc0e-db9e-42f3-ae4a-2c96b6fae74c:
Incorrect because there are two mistakes: (1) multiplying ROE with payout ratio instead of retention ratio when computing g, and (2) using retention ratio in the numerator instead of the payout ratio:

g = Dividend payout ratio × ROE = 0.40 × 15 = 6%

P0/E1 = p/(r – g) = 0.60/(0.12 – 0.06) = 10

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Fairborn-12
entry.itemBody: Which of the following categories of private debt most likely has the highest level of risk for an investor?

answerFeedback.52d97303-2d92-45a3-bb0b-3be56c9fd2bf: Incorrect because investments in private capital vary in terms of risk and return across the corporate capital structure hierarchy. Typically, private equity, as the riskiest alternative, offers the highest returns, with private debt returns declining on a continuum down to the safest, most secured form of debt—infrastructure debt.
answerFeedback.56f63011-6b7e-42ed-a501-b65ceabdc8a7: Correct because mezzanine debt is riskier than senior secure debt which is riskier than infrastructure debt (graphically displayed by the Private Capital Risk and Return Levels by Category chart). Because of its typically junior ranking and its usually unsecured status, mezzanine debt is riskier than senior secured debt. Investments in private capital vary in terms of risk and return across the corporate capital structure hierarchy. Typically, private equity, as the riskiest alternative, offers the highest returns, with private debt returns declining on a continuum down to the safest, most secured form of debt—infrastructure debt.
answerFeedback.cb9bc2dc-aa46-46e7-bd72-e09f41567f2e: Incorrect because senior direct lending is less risky than mezzanine debt. Because of its typically junior ranking and its usually unsecured status, mezzanine debt is riskier than senior secured debt.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-RID-Elliott-Equity-005
entry.itemBody: A 5% decline in the value of a security held on margin reduces an investor's equity value by 20%. After the price decline, the leverage ratio of the position is:

answerFeedback.4d53d88d-21cc-4b32-ab5a-96e6cbd20990: Incorrect because ​​​1/25% = 4 and is the correct leverage ratio prior to the price decline. Once the price declines, leverage increases.
answerFeedback.927348cf-e598-4971-b321-5506d0ecd085: Correct because the equity value decline is four times more than the security price, indicating initial leverage of 4. With a price decline of 5%, the total position value falls by 5%, however because of the 4 times leverage, equity falls by 20%.  Accordingly, the new leverage ratio = 4 × (1 – 5%) / (1 – 20%) = 3.8 / 0.8 = 4.75.
answerFeedback.9866e52d-cacc-4f68-826d-40aeccc1b9bc: Incorrect because a leverage ratio of 5 results when the numerator portion of the calculation is not reduced by 5% (which is an incorrect calculation), i.e. new leverage ratio = 4 / (1 – 20%) = 4 / 0.8 = 5.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516046
entry.itemBody: A closed-end fund is trading at a premium to its NAV. This scenario most likely reflects:

answerFeedback.14bb614d-87f8-4881-87aa-f13d3fe5771c: Incorrect because excess redemption demand suggests selling pressure, which could indicate a discount to NAV.
answerFeedback.c9a671f4-1e4c-46fc-a647-9d0617d7c110: Incorrect because concerns about the quality of management could suggest a discount from NAV.
answerFeedback.cc4c111f-ca60-4ab4-a93f-fd587496e932: Correct because closed-end funds may trade at a premium (discount) to NAV when investors believe that the portfolio securities are undervalued (overvalued).

choices.itemBody: A. concerns about the quality of management.
B. excess demand for redemption of the shares.
C. a belief that the portfolio securities are undervalued.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-05
entry.itemBody: Which of the following US sovereign securities is a pure discount bond?

answerFeedback.06ca228a-0093-4bb6-9975-72c4b0646d6a: Correct because sovereign debt issues include the following: Short-term securities (with maturities ranging from 1 to 12 months), often known as Treasury bills, which are usually zero-coupon instruments sold at a discount to par.
answerFeedback.35557d63-1c07-488f-8ff2-29c320d5ebae: Incorrect because sovereign debt issues include the following: Short-term securities (with maturities ranging from 1 to 12 months), often known as Treasury bills, which are usually zero-coupon instruments sold at a discount to par. Medium- and long-term securities often known as Treasury notes and bonds. Fixed-rate coupon instruments in the domestic currency are most common, but sovereigns also issue floating-rate, inflation-linked, and foreign currency instruments.
answerFeedback.787a93b8-7f51-4f69-9d44-ef93634aa397: Incorrect because sovereign debt issues include the following: Short-term securities (with maturities ranging from 1 to 12 months), often known as Treasury bills, which are usually zero-coupon instruments sold at a discount to par. Medium- and long-term securities often known as Treasury notes and bonds. Fixed-rate coupon instruments in the domestic currency are most common, but sovereigns also issue floating-rate, inflation-linked, and foreign currency instruments.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08576
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company:

Earnings retention rate 55%
ROE 20%

If the required rate of return is 15%, the justified forward P/E of the company is closest to:

answerFeedback.0808409b-6928-4bb3-9d7c-4d99d0b5d386: Incorrect because in this case the earnings retention rate is used instead of the dividend payout ratio in the formula for the justified forward P/E, which is:   P 0 E 1 = D 1 / E 1 r - g = p r - g  where p is the dividend payout ratio, r is the required rate of return and g is the dividend growth rate. In this case we use p = 0.55 instead of p = 1 – 0.55 = 0.45. The dividend growth rate is: g = earnings retention rate × ROE =  0.55 × 0.2 = 0.11. Thus, the justified forward P/E is p / (r – g) = 0.55 / (0.15 – 0.11) = 13.75.
answerFeedback.5f44da17-ca12-4d19-8967-14908c3edf44: Correct because the justified forward P/E can be calculated as P 0 E 1 = D 1 / E 1 r - g = p r - g  where p is the dividend payout ratio, r is the required rate of return and g is the dividend growth rate. By definition earnings retention rate = (1 – Dividend payout ratio). It follows that p = 1 – earnings retention rate = 1 – 0.55 = 0.45. The dividend growth rate is: g = earnings retention rate × ROE = 0.55 × 0.2 = 0.11. Thus, the justified forward P/E is p / (r – g) = 0.45 / (0.15 – 0.11) = 11.25.
answerFeedback.f8c145e4-2cb3-40c3-8600-7ab498c642c3: Incorrect because in this case the dividend payout ratio is used during the calculation of the dividend growth rate instead of the earnings retention rate. The justified forward P/E can be calculated as P0E1=D1/E1r-g=pr-g where p is the dividend payout ratio, r is the required rate of return and g is the dividend growth rate. By definition earnings retention rate = (1 – Dividend payout ratio). It follows that p = 1 – earnings retention rate = 1 – 0.55 = 0.45. The dividend growth rate is incorrectly calculated as: g = earnings retention rate × ROE = 0.45 × 0.2 = 0.09. Thus, the justified forward P/E is p / (r – g) = 0.45 / (0.15 – 0.09) = 7.5.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FI-Groenning-03
entry.itemBody: The pass-through rate of a mortgage-pass through security is:

answerFeedback.374f927b-0681-46f0-91d9-5cdbcf8ae588: Incorrect because the pass-through rate is lower than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing and other administrative fees.
answerFeedback.5e371910-72ea-410d-a968-350f7a9e9278: Incorrect because the pass-through rate is lower than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing and other administrative fees.
answerFeedback.e8f8c256-414d-4584-b8d6-4daeb3c156d7: Correct because the pass-through rate is lower than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing and other administrative fees.

choices.itemBody: A. lower than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool.
B. equal to the mortgage rate on the underlying pool.
C. greater than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lamba-02
entry.itemBody: Consider a call option trading for $2.00 with an exercise price of $38.00. If the price of the underlying at expiration is $42.00, the payoff for the call option seller is:

answerFeedback.245c79a7-ec3c-44c1-ae8b-4a147cb94849: Incorrect because the call buyer’s (not seller’s) payoff is calculated as: Max(0, ST – X) = Max(0, $42.00 – $38.00) = $4.00.
answerFeedback.32cd6a42-13b3-4583-91d7-99118fdc5f43: Correct because the call seller’s payoff as:  –cT = –Max(0, ST – X) = –Max(0, $42.00 – $38.00) = –$4.00.
answerFeedback.51c5b52b-4b81-4e30-845d-d6a39fc0603c: Incorrect because the call seller’s profit (not payoff) is calculated as: –Max(0, ST – X) + c0 = –Max(0, $42.00 – $38.00) + $2.00 = –$2.00.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FI-Hung-01
entry.itemBody: A credit issuer rating assigned by a rating agency is based on:

answerFeedback.75cf18e8-407f-4e2f-a707-31bce6325097: Correct because an issuer credit rating is meant to address an obligor’s overall creditworthiness — its ability and willingness to make timely payments of interest and principal on its debt. The issuer credit rating usually applies to its senior unsecured debt.
answerFeedback.a09daa95-2b82-4c40-b810-78bc271ddfa0: Incorrect because an issue rating, not an issuer rating, should consider ranking in the capital structure. Issue ratings refer to specific financial obligations of an issuer and take into consideration such factors as ranking in the capital structure (e.g., secured or subordinated).
answerFeedback.b180f51b-934e-4d2c-b8d0-1504a00d4e9b: Incorrect because an issue rating is notched from the issuer rating, not the other way round. The rating agencies have adopted a notching process whereby their credit ratings on issues can be moved up or down from the issuer rating,

choices.itemBody: A. the notching adjustment of a specific bond of the issuer.
B. the ranking of a specific bond in the issuer's capital structure.
C. the issuer's ability and willingness to service its senior unsecured debt.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06421
entry.itemBody: The price sensitivity of a bond to a change in the benchmark yield curve is the:

answerFeedback.33836092-9881-41d9-aaff-d8b0d0fc9643: Incorrect because Macaulay duration is a weighted average of the time to receipt of the bonds promised payments, where the weights are the shares of the full price that correspond to each of the bond's promised payments.
answerFeedback.b8e2131d-7cd0-40f1-a89b-b6c326cc8eb0: Incorrect because the calculation of the modified duration (ModDur) statistic of a bond requires a simple adjustment to Macaulay duration. It is the Macaulay duration statistic divided by one plus the yield per period. Although modified duration might seem to be just a Macaulay duration with minor adjustments, it has an important application in risk management: Modified duration provides an estimate of the percentage price change for a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity. Effective duration is the best duration measure for a given change in benchmark yield and not modified duration which is the best measure for a given change in a bond's yield-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.c50b4728-13db-4a06-9759-afb7671da587: Correct because an approach to assess the interest rate risk of a bond is to estimate the percentage change in price given a change in benchmark yield curve - for example, the government par curve. This estimate, which is very similar to the formula for approximate modified duration, is called the effective duration. The effective duration of a bond is the sensitivity of the bond's price to a change in a benchmark yield curve. Effective duration is essential to the measurement of the interest rate risk of a complex bond, such as a bond that contains an embedded call option. Therefore, effective duration is the best duration measure of the change to a bond's price given a change in a benchmark yield curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Deriv-Hambusch-14
entry.itemBody: A transaction setup to absorb the variable cash flow of a floating-rate asset can be described as a:

answerFeedback.1179179c-e5a7-4b5e-9e83-b768b650361e: Incorrect because a fair value hedge designation applies when a derivative is deemed to offset the fluctuation in fair value of an asset or liability. A fair value hedge type is not aimed at absorbing variable cash flow of a floating-rate asset.
answerFeedback.a9bdfaa9-868d-4c6a-adc4-1a15981192cf: Incorrect because net investment hedges occur when either a foreign currency bond or a derivative such as an FX swap or forward is used to offset the exchange rate risk of the equity of a foreign operation. A net investment hedge type is not aimed at absorbing variable cash flow of a floating-rate asset.
answerFeedback.f670151f-38f8-4b3b-96a5-7e50778a50a7: Correct because derivatives designated as absorbing the variable cash flow of a floating-rate asset or liability such as foreign exchange, interest rates, or commodities are referred to as cash flow hedges.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-21
entry.itemBody: Measuring the duration of a bond portfolio as a weighted average of the individual bond durations:

answerFeedback.4d80ea02-9c3b-40ec-9cf7-dce7c7d68781: Correct because the weighted average of the individual bond durations that comprise the portfolio implicitly assumes a parallel shift in the yield curve. A parallel yield curve shift implies that all rates change by the same amount in the same direction. In reality, interest rate changes frequently result in a steeper or flatter yield curve.
answerFeedback.646f4893-0e9a-4a02-a405-dbbe05fa6bed: Incorrect because the weighted average of the individual bond durations that comprise the portfolio implicitly assumes a parallel shift in the yield curve. A parallel yield curve shift implies that all rates change by the same amount in the same direction. In reality, interest rate changes frequently result in a steeper or flatter yield curve.
answerFeedback.bdf529a5-1431-4e71-862d-8a6c7a2d46fe: Incorrect because the weighted average of the individual bond durations that comprise the portfolio is easily used as a measure of interest rate risk.

choices.itemBody: A. is difficult to use as a measure of interest rate risk.
B. assumes the yield curve shifts in a parallel manner.
C. assumes the yield curve shifts in a non-parallel manner.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-29
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in $ millions) about a private equity fund:

  Investment A Investment B Total
Initial cost 100 150 250
Profit/loss –50 30 –20

The manager's incentive fee is 20% of the profits. If no clawback provision applies, the total incentive fee (in $ millions) under an American-style waterfall is:

answerFeedback.1616c376-d91b-42fb-98ff-f1923545a226: Incorrect because it calculated the incentive fee based on the total loss of –$20 million under a European-style whole-of-fund waterfall instead of an American-style deal-by-deal waterfall. Consequently, total incentive fee payable = MAX [$0, –$4 million] = $0. Note that while the incentive fee is calculated on the total profit/loss of the fund, the minimum incentive fee is $0 instead of –$20 million × 20% = –$4 million.
answerFeedback.d8afebc3-d723-4d72-a576-b9babe46edc7: Correct because it calculated the incentive fee based on the Investment B's profit of $30 million under an American-style deal-by-deal waterfall, and correctly excluded Investment A which incurred a loss. Total incentive fee payable = Incentive fee of Investment B = $30 million × 20% = $6 million.
answerFeedback.e39c04ea-2e52-4d13-823b-726c61144b40: Incorrect because it calculated the incentive fee based on the total loss of –$20 million. Note that under a European-style whole-of-fund waterfall, while the incentive fee is calculated on the total profit/loss of the fund, the minimum incentive fee would be $0 instead of –$20 million × 20% = –$4 million.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606044
entry.itemBody:
Selected information about shares of two companies is provided in the following table:

Stock Standard Deviation Correlation of Returns* Portfolio Weights
Cable Incorporated 30% 0.65 68%
GPT Company 20% 0.65 32%

* Correlation of returns between Cable Incorporated and GPT Company.

The standard deviation of returns of the portfolio formed with these two stocks is closest to:

answerFeedback.6c7a5070-adcc-433b-9c31-865ffeffeea2: Incorrect. This incorrect calculation is the weighted standard deviations = 0.68 × 0.30 + 0.32 × 0.20 = 0.268.
answerFeedback.856e768e-5868-4b89-b4e7-3271333c9ca3: Incorrect. The incorrect calculation excludes the standard deviation from the third part of the equation; it also does not take the square root. This is incorrect calculation is [(0.682)(0.32) + (0.322)(0.22) + 2(0.68)(0.32)(0.65) = 0.3285.
answerFeedback.9ab98d48-8f7f-4ea2-9732-b51f6c19eba2:
Correct because the portfolio standard deviation for a two stock portfolio, σp, is calculated as follows:

σp = [w12σ12 + w22σ22 + 2w1w2ρ12σ1σ2]1/2

 

Where

w = weight of each stock

σ = standard deviation

ρ12 = the correlation of returns between Stock 1 and Stock 2

 

Plugging in the numbers

σp = [(0.682)( 0.32)+( 0.322)( 0.22)+2(0.68)(0.32)(0.65)(0.3(0.2)]1/2  = 0.2504.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Crutu-05
entry.itemBody: Market prices are most likely accepted as accurately reflecting intrinsic values in:

answerFeedback.ce6c1816-b10f-4f5c-a16d-28fb9edd61f5: Incorrect because if investors believe an asset market is relatively inefficient, they may try to develop an independent estimate of intrinsic value, indicating market prices are not likely to be accepted as reflecting intrinsic values.
answerFeedback.e031ba33-42e8-44ad-9f83-7fc1bbf8a716: Correct because if investors believe a market is highly efficient, they will usually accept market prices as accurately reflecting intrinsic values.
answerFeedback.f820f695-c3fd-44d6-b1f1-b0d087cedaeb: Incorrect because if investors believe an asset market is relatively inefficient, they may try to develop an independent estimate of intrinsic value, indicating market prices are not likely to be accepted as reflecting intrinsic values.

choices.itemBody: B. a highly efficient market only.
C. both an inefficient market and a highly efficient market.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Islam-08
entry.itemBody: Sponsored depository receipts are most likely subject to:

answerFeedback.0f287237-4334-454f-b6d9-54aa7fe9efdf: Incorrect because sponsored DRs are generally subject to greater reporting requirements than unsponsored DRs.
answerFeedback.bcf205c7-19cd-4bac-8a3c-e98be362bd09: Incorrect because sponsored DRs are generally subject to greater reporting requirements than unsponsored DRs.
answerFeedback.ee540f6e-d1f4-4523-983c-f03e2dc5a29b: Correct because sponsored DRs are generally subject to greater reporting requirements than unsponsored DRs.

choices.itemBody: A. less reporting requirements than unsponsored ones.
B. the same level of reporting requirements as unsponsored ones.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-29
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following conditions most likely results in wider credit spreads?

answerFeedback.61a716e9-069e-40e6-891b-6472c62cd22c: Correct because in periods of heavy new issue supply, credit spreads will widen if there is insufficient demand. In periods of high demand for bonds, spreads will move tighter.
answerFeedback.86f113f9-b62f-4b21-9bb5-00f763f6fabe: Incorrect because a strengthening economy will cause credit spreads to narrow.
answerFeedback.896911b5-250c-4a07-932b-dba7d836de96: Incorrect because spreads are tightest at or near the top of the credit cycle.

choices.itemBody: C. A period of heavy new issue supply

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Gagne-13
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely an application of the CAPM?

answerFeedback.63abe492-62aa-4558-8889-54b1cabd7f89: Incorrect because a limitation of the CAPM is that it is a single-period model that does not consider multi-period implications or investment objectives of future periods, which can lead to myopic and suboptimal investment decisions.
answerFeedback.bb27b2a9-6dc6-4d44-a787-b16ee09986bb: Incorrect because a limitation of the CAPM is that it is a single-factor model. Only systematic risk or beta risk is priced in the CAPM. Thus, the CAPM states that no other investment characteristics should be considered in estimating returns.
answerFeedback.c61ed6e8-93a4-428c-8cfa-24f63fa1fd5f: Correct because applications of the CAPM include comparison of the actual return of a portfolio or portfolio manager with the CAPM return for performance appraisal.

choices.itemBody: C. Estimating expected returns using multiple investment factors

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-08
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about market efficiency is most accurate? In a:

answerFeedback.45bde1a5-459e-4caa-ab19-cf2dff112451: Incorrect because securities markets are weak-form efficient, and therefore, investors cannot earn abnormal returns by trading on the basis of past trends in price (using technical analysis).
answerFeedback.6142a211-eb02-4095-879c-828a243713d9: Correct because in the case of a strong-form efficient market, insiders would not be able to earn abnormal returns from trading on the basis of private information.
answerFeedback.cacff3f3-2a79-4e31-9f81-a691eef3f8c8: Incorrect because if securities markets are weak-form and semi-strong-form efficient, the implication is that active trading, whether attempting to exploit price patterns or public information, is not likely to generate abnormal returns. In other words, active portfolio managers cannot beat the market on a consistent basis.

choices.itemBody: A. weak-form efficient market, technical analysis generates abnormal returns over the long run.
B. semi-strong-form efficient market, active portfolio managers outperform the market on a consistent basis.
C. strong-form efficient market, insiders would not be able to earn abnormal returns from trading on private information.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-22
entry.itemBody: If the 1-year spot rate is 3% and the 2-year spot rate is 4.5%, the 1y1y implied forward rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.499526d8-c4fa-48b8-b919-37a694d0e9f4:
Incorrect because the exponents are missing in the formula.

≠ (1 + zA)  × (1 + IFR,A,B–A) = (1 + zB)

= (1 + 0.03) × (1 + IFR,A,B–A) = (1 + 4.5)

=1.045/1.03 = 1.01456 ≈ 1.46%.
answerFeedback.acee0cb5-eb46-4da3-850f-21e1538afa91:
Correct because the implied forward rate can be calculated as:

(1 + zA) A × (1 + IFR,A,B–A) B–A = (1 + zB) B, where:

zA = the 1 year spot rate

zB = the 2 year spot rate IFR = the implied forward rate IFR = (1 + 0.03)  × (1 + IFR,A,B–A) B–A = (1 + 0.045)2

= 1.0452/1.03 = 1.0602 ≈ 6.02%.
answerFeedback.d21591e3-2014-4c31-bda2-4509a8f4d628: Incorrect because this is simply the average of the one and two year spot rates, not the implied forward rate = (3% + 4.5%) / 2 = 3.75%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601048
entry.itemBody: Exercise of a European put option is most likely justified if:

answerFeedback.13ebcdc2-a2a7-4760-ab94-fa847581594c: Incorrect because an out-of-the-money option should not be exercised and will expire worthless.
answerFeedback.41fb999c-6d0e-4c7a-9314-18ee8d9887d7: Incorrect because an option that generates a negative cash flow when exercised should not be exercised.
answerFeedback.f6b1e1d1-dfce-403a-a324-4b6d1edbc5c2: Correct because if the exercise price exceeds the value of the underlying at expiration, the option has positive exercise value and may be exercised.

choices.itemBody: A. the option is out of the money.
C. the exercise price exceeds the value of the underlying.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-RID-Elliott-Equity-004
entry.itemBody: If a stock purchased with 60% margin declines 25%, the investor's return on equity is closest to:

answerFeedback.c35a64f4-51ee-47a1-9c64-b2061daa9ed2: Incorrect because if 40% rather than 60% is incorrectly used to calculate leverage, leverage = 1/0.4 ≈ 2.5, multiplied by the 25% decline ≈ a 63% decline.
answerFeedback.cf0bcbc0-0adb-4e0e-a28f-7e604a6ee6de: Correct because 60% margin equals leverage of 1/0.6 ≈ 1.67, multiplied by the 25% decline ≈ a 42% decline.
answerFeedback.e7155fb6-65ad-4b87-83e2-c5d86f453c86: Incorrect because 85% is the sum of 60% and 25%, the two numbers provided in the stem, and is not a meaningful number or calculation.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427026
entry.itemBody: Do management fees get paid to the manager of a hedge fund regardless of the fund’s performance?

answerFeedback.24252094-89da-4a40-bd59-78dc276c179b: Incorrect because the management fee is paid regardless of the value of the assets in the fund.
answerFeedback.ab8720dc-412d-4447-aea6-3ea2831febb5: Correct because regardless of performance, the management fee is always paid to the fund manager.
answerFeedback.eb734e2e-9a10-4106-ab13-e53a8c178bca: Incorrect because the gross return can be at any level and the manager is still paid the management fee.

choices.itemBody: B. No, only when the fund’s gross return is positive
C. No, only when the fund’s net asset value exceeds the previous high-water mark

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04902
entry.itemBody: Which of the following equations best describes put–call parity for European options?

answerFeedback.06f71735-b79d-44db-94b9-03d01fcb664e: Incorrect because, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer, according to put-call parity, S0 + p0 = c0 + X / (1 + r)T. Rearranging, we can get S0 = c0 − p0+ X / (1 + r)T. Therefore, S0 ≠ c0 − p0− X / (1 + r)T.
answerFeedback.6aa9575d-ed45-4e97-b8df-ffcf2bba9d09: Incorrect because, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer, according to put-parity, S0 + p0 = c0 + X / (1 + r)T. Rearranging the put-call parity equation, we get c0 = p0+S0 − X / (1 + r)T. Therefore, c0 ≠ p0−S0 − X / (1 + r)T.
answerFeedback.d2d82956-b079-4436-a6f5-12403e7301e5: Correct because S0 + p0 = c0 + X / (1 + r)T. This relationship is known as put-call parity. Rearranging the equation, we can get: p0 = c0 − S0 + X / (1 + r)T. That is, long put = long call, short asset, long bond.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Agarwal-11
entry.itemBody: In the binomial option pricing model, the price of a call option will increase when:

answerFeedback.99dfa6dc-dfce-412b-b63a-055766df78d2: Incorrect because the value of call option = c0 = (πc1+ + (1 – π)c1–)/(1 + r), where π = (1 + r – d)/(u – d), the probabilities of the up and down moves, q and 1 – q, do not appear in the formula. The call option price is effectively independent of the up move probability.
answerFeedback.b85f2aa2-90b1-42e5-9dcd-a358e3a3261a: Correct because if volatility increases, the difference between S1+ and S1− increases, which widens the range between c1+ and c1−, leading to a higher option value.
answerFeedback.f34ae894-bb38-45c2-b7aa-b478de65d545: Incorrect because the value of call option = c0 = (πc1+ + (1 – π)c1–)/(1 + r), where π = (1 + r – d)/(u – d), the formula takes the form of an expected future value, the numerator, discounted at the risk-free rate. Since the expected future value is discounted at the risk-free rate, a higher risk-free rate will result in a lower call option price.

choices.itemBody: B. the volatility of the underlying increases.
C. the probability of an upward movement in the underlying increases.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Glover-05
entry.itemBody: Issuers' disclosures about operating costs are most likely:

answerFeedback.144b0292-5982-45f6-a8c2-6e0f686dd149: Correct because issuers' disclosures about operating costs are typically less detailed than revenue disclosures. Rather than modeling costs separately for different geographic regions, business segments, or product lines, analysts are often forced to use more aggregated forecast objects such as consolidated financial statement lines (e.g., cost of sales, SG&A) or summary measures like EBITDA margins on a consolidated or segment basis.
answerFeedback.87c8452f-29ac-4aee-8b75-0e98b57ef3f4: Incorrect because issuers' disclosures about operating costs are typically less detailed than, not as detailed as, revenue disclosures.
answerFeedback.da8cf115-5cd5-4ba9-9512-b83bbe57c583: Incorrect because issuers' disclosures about operating costs are typically less detailed than revenue disclosures.

choices.itemBody: A. less detailed than their revenue disclosures.
B. just as detailed as their revenue disclosures.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Berlinicke-16
entry.itemBody: The industry growth style of the crude oil sector is best characterized as:

answerFeedback.59e7defe-4635-4817-bb9e-68514de22bae: Incorrect because utilities, beverages and pharmaceuticals are examples of defensive mature industries given in the reading, not crude oil which is a cyclical mature industry instead.
answerFeedback.9ce43b94-a672-4fe5-89bb-6bae034d4b30: Correct because crude oil together with natural gas and freight transportation are examples of cyclical mature industries given in the reading.
answerFeedback.d0460305-d490-42ba-a802-25c842d89cff: Incorrect because biotechnology, software and gaming are examples of defensive growth industries given in the reading, not crude oil which is a cyclical mature industry instead.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-PM-Y.Zhang-07
entry.itemBody: In which section of an IPS is the rebalancing policy most likely found?

answerFeedback.002869dc-fc5e-4507-9512-8256166a2ca8: Incorrect because Evaluation and Review provides guidance on obtaining feedback on investment results. It is Appendices that details (A) Strategic Asset Allocation (B) Rebalancing Policy.
answerFeedback.124a0732-24a4-45bb-b18c-cabbecdf7912: Incorrect because Investment Guidelines provides information about how policy should be executed (e.g., on the permissible use of leverage and derivatives) and on specific types of assets excluded from investment, if any. It is Appendices that details (A) Strategic Asset Allocation (B) Rebalancing Policy.
answerFeedback.751e07d0-f364-46ae-9cfe-18a7695d0f47: Correct because Appendices details (A) Strategic Asset Allocation (B) Rebalancing Policy. Many investors specify a strategic asset allocation (SAA), also known as the policy portfolio, which is the baseline allocation of portfolio assets to asset classes in view of the investor’s investment objectives.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-24
entry.itemBody: For a given currency and tenor, a bond's yield spread over the standard swap rate is best described as the:

answerFeedback.10c41853-3a44-4e7f-b545-527c88d05e59: Incorrect because the G-spread and I-spread each use the same discount rate for each cash flow. Another approach is to calculate a constant yield spread over a government (or interest rate swap) spot curve instead. This spread is known as the zero-volatility spread (Z-spread) of a bond over the benchmark rate.
answerFeedback.6be391df-8d45-4785-a6bb-38b75708b6a0: Incorrect because the yield spread in basis points over an actual or interpolated government bond is known as the G-spread. The spread over a government bond is the return for bearing greater credit, liquidity, and other risks relative to the sovereign bond.
answerFeedback.6c0bb823-e1fd-4590-825a-0c6bbc71f0b5: Correct because the yield spread of a specific bond over the standard swap rate in that currency of the same tenor is known as the I-spread or interpolated spread to the swap curve. This yield spread over MRR allows comparison of bonds with differing credit and liquidity risks against an interbank lending benchmark.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Ermogenous-02
entry.itemBody: The minimum rate of return required by investors to purchase an equity security is most likely approximated by the company's:

answerFeedback.3ed8a137-352c-49df-a52a-398aad1dadb9: Incorrect because the WACC represents the minimum required rate of return that the company must earn on its long-term investments to satisfy all providers of capital, i.e. both debt holders and equity investors not just equity investors.
answerFeedback.7d657d0d-ce82-4a04-8cd1-9a6acc58631f: Correct because the company’s cost of equity is often used as a proxy for the investors’ minimum required rate of return.
answerFeedback.ffa6358b-af11-4518-8809-e2c8f0c2d31b: Incorrect because when investors purchase the company’s equity securities, their minimum required rate of return is based on the future cash flows they expect to receive. Return on equity is a historical accounting measure which measures the total return on the firm's book value, therefore it may or may not approximate investors' minimum required rate of return.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00455
entry.itemBody: When defining an asset class for the purpose of asset allocation, an investor should ensure that assets in the class are relatively:

answerFeedback.65233f38-782a-46bd-92b4-0bb7e15c403d: Incorrect because an asset class should contain relatively homogeneous assets while providing diversification relative to other asset classes. In statistical terms, risk and return expectations should be similar and paired correlations of asset should be relatively high within an asset class but should be lower versus assets in other asset classes.
answerFeedback.87bdccd1-7faa-4015-8a26-c5fdb92319e4: Correct because an asset class should contain relatively homogeneous assets while providing diversification relative to other asset classes. In statistical terms, risk and return expectations should be similar and paired correlations of asset should be relatively high within an asset class but should be lower versus assets in other asset classes.
answerFeedback.d41192e5-bd31-4bc8-9f82-ee33abfc11ed: Incorrect because an asset class should contain relatively homogeneous assets while providing diversification relative to other asset classes. In statistical terms, risk and return expectations should be similar and paired correlations of asset should be relatively high within an asset class but should be lower versus assets in other asset classes.

choices.itemBody: A. homogeneous and have low paired correlations with other asset classes.
B. homogeneous and have high paired correlations with other asset classes.
C. heterogeneous and have low paired correlations with other asset classes.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607041
entry.itemBody: For an option-free, fixed-rate bond the coupon reinvestment risk most likely dominates market price risk when the investment horizon is:

answerFeedback.0a2e6462-46af-4a13-9c03-c552d6117fdf: Correct because for an option-free, fixed-rate bond when the investment horizon is greater than the Macaulay duration, the coupon reinvestment risk will tend to dominate market price risk. In such situations, the investor’s risk is to lower interest rates.
answerFeedback.33860f05-5a83-4cd0-a4e0-02b4a791f157: Incorrect because for an option-free, fixed-rate bond when the investment horizon is greater than the Macaulay duration, the coupon reinvestment risk will tend to dominate market price risk.
answerFeedback.5e2fb06f-3d79-49da-9a80-2a2a6d4d189a: Incorrect because for an option-free, fixed-rate bond when the investment horizon is greater than the Macaulay duration, the coupon reinvestment risk will tend to dominate market price risk.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the Macaulay duration of the bond.
B. equal to the Macaulay duration of the bond.
C. greater than the Macaulay duration of the bond.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06783
entry.itemBody: An investor owns a stock trading at $22 per share and would like to place an order to sell the position should the stock ever trade at or below $20 per share. The order most likely is:

answerFeedback.19fa26da-5ae6-4097-90c1-7a480349baef: Incorrect because this order will sell the stock if it trades at or above $20/share, but not if it trades below $20/share.
answerFeedback.2a5957d8-4bd5-4fbe-9433-dce8344680da: Correct because this order will sell the position at $20/share or under, at all prices, at the market. If the price falls to or below $20, the market order becomes valid and it should immediately execute at the best price then available in the market.
answerFeedback.c839059a-146e-453d-9321-4d417dda1c90: Incorrect because this order will sell the stock at $20/share, but not if it trades below/through $20/share.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-PM-Conover-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following most likely has the greatest impact on portfolio performance?﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿

answerFeedback.70a5f097-bfc1-4f85-b9c0-5900301e12f2: Incorrect because although all decisions have an effect on portfolio performance, the asset allocation decision is commonly viewed as having the greatest impact. The selection of securities is not an asset allocation decision.
answerFeedback.b1392d1e-7ba5-4e03-8a9a-2c87998c4f78: Incorrect because although all decisions have an effect on portfolio performance, the asset allocation decision is commonly viewed as having the greatest impact. The trading of securities is not an asset allocation decision.
answerFeedback.f31cd7cb-dd1e-4d2b-b535-3fe4b7e96d12: Correct because decisions that need to be made in the asset allocation of the portfolio include the distribution between equities, fixed-income securities, and cash; sub-asset classes, such as corporate and government bonds; and geographical weightings within asset classes. Although all decisions have an effect on portfolio performance, the asset allocation decision is commonly viewed as having the greatest impact.

choices.itemBody: C. The trading of securities within asset classes﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02166
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, the effect of a cash dividend on shareholders' wealth is most likely equivalent to the effect of a:

answerFeedback.146b4c86-1dbd-4a2e-af88-12e9d185707c: Incorrect because stock splits and reverse stock splits are similar to stock (not cash) dividends in that they have no economic effect on the company or shareholders.
answerFeedback.97801015-0253-4397-a4cc-996c84b137a1: Correct because a share repurchase is viewed as equivalent to the payment of cash dividends of equal value in terms of the effect on shareholders' wealth, all other things being equal.
answerFeedback.d50e22c8-59ba-450c-b2a6-a583765f8b89: Incorrect because stock splits and reverse stock splits are similar to stock (not cash) dividends in that they have no economic effect on the company or shareholders.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516071
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements regarding a commodity index is most accurate?

answerFeedback.1993512c-b494-42d2-8f4c-83b7a4127984: Incorrect because different weighting methods lead to different exposure to specific commodities and result in different risk and return profiles. Unlike commodity indexes, broad equity and fixed-income indexes that target the same markets share similar risk and return profiles.
answerFeedback.617482d2-391e-4d28-a053-b259a8237dab: Correct because the performance of commodity indexes can be different from their underlying commodities because the indexes consist of futures contracts on the commodities rather than the actual commodities. Commodity index returns reflect the risk-free interest rate, the changes in future prices, and the roll yield.
answerFeedback.f12c98b0-805a-4c75-a8b3-14a17fb6e191: Incorrect because commodity indexes do not have an obvious weighting mechanism; therefore, commodity index providers create their own weighting methods.

choices.itemBody: A. Commodity indexes commonly use an equal-weighting method.
B. Commodity indexes in the same markets will share similar risk and return profiles.
C. Commodity index returns differ from the changes in the prices of their underlying commodities.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10999
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a portfolio and the market:

  Return Standard Deviation of Returns
Portfolio 11% 18%
Market 10% 20%

If the risk-free rate is 4%, the portfolio's M2 alpha is closest to:

answerFeedback.a1000304-cfa2-47c4-b5bc-14af49a3e041:
Incorrect because the market risk premium is replaced with the portfolio risk premium in the last section of the formula.

M2 alpha = (Rp – Rf) × (σm/σp) – (Rp – Rf)

M2 alpha = (0.11 – 0.04) × (0.20/0.18) – (0.11 – 0.04) = 0.07 × 1.1111 – 0.07 = 0.778% ≈ 0.8%.
answerFeedback.af4b0b6a-3d9e-4019-a30b-6306a5d66842:
Incorrect because the standard deviation ratio is inverted:

M2 alpha = (Rp – Rf) × (σp /σm) + Rf – Rm

M2 alpha = (0.11 – 0.04) × (0.18/0.20) + 0.04 – 0.10 = 0.07 × 0.90 – 0.06 = 0.3%.

Alternatively, it applies the ratio of standard deviations to the market risk premium rather than the portfolio's risk premium:

M2 alpha = (Rp – Rf) – (Rm – Rf) × (σm/σp)

M2 alpha = (0.11 – 0.04) – (0.10 – 0.04) × (0.20/0.18) = 0.07 – 0.06 × 1.1111 = 0.333% ≈ 0.3%.
answerFeedback.c9b6ee0d-296a-47ab-b902-afde7e90c9ad:
Correct because the difference between the risk-adjusted performance (M2) of the portfolio and the performance of the market is frequently referred to as M2 alpha. Applying the formula yields:

M2 alpha = (Rp – Rf) × (σm/σp) + Rf – Rm

M2 alpha = (0.11 – 0.04) × (0.20/0.18) + 0.04 – 0.10 = 0.07 × 1.1111 – 0.06 = 1.778% ≈ 1.8%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Tsependa-03
entry.itemBody: When developing an IPS, an investor's desire to earn an inflation-adjusted annual rate of return of at least 2% is best classified as a(n):

answerFeedback.5d15686e-8f57-4ef0-aaec-f093f4ec7ddf: Correct because return objectives may be stated on an absolute or a relative basis. As an example of an absolute objective, the client may want to achieve a particular percentage rate of return. This objective could be a nominal rate of return or could be expressed in real (inflation-adjusted) terms.
answerFeedback.98637442-2364-42f0-bbfb-669a6bee8afb: Incorrect because the objective provided in the stem is a return objective, and not a risk objective.
answerFeedback.f69330fc-649a-4a76-b2aa-40d8e0f5f218: Incorrect because the return objective is formulated in absolute terms, even though it is stated in real (inflation-adjusted) terms. Alternatively, the return objective can be stated on a relative basis—for example, relative to a benchmark return, which is not the case in the stem.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601043
entry.itemBody: If a forward contract requires no cash outlay at initiation, it is most likely true that at initiation:

answerFeedback.87c4d37b-ec14-44a3-92ca-db2a6e7c0671: Incorrect. Value is zero; price is a positive number.
answerFeedback.9d777e91-8f4b-4978-b614-30716ffe5ecc: Incorrect. Value is zero; price is a positive number.
answerFeedback.fb677196-1e33-4751-93df-cfca52f9eb9f: Correct. At initiation, value is equal to zero. Price is a positive number that states the amount that must be paid when the purchase takes place.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09105
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company's common stock and the market:

Dividend per share (D0) $3.00
Dividend payout ratio 25%
Equity beta 1.6
Expected risk-free rate of return 3.5%
Expected market rate of return 9.0%
ROE 7.0%

Using the Gordon growth model, the stock's intrinsic value is closest to:

answerFeedback.1524bcd6-8d79-41f1-8194-dfee47efe71b:
Incorrect because this answer incorrectly applies D0 (instead of D1) in the formula V0 = D0(1 + g)/(r – g) = D1/(r – g).  That is:

Step 1: calculate g, where: g = b × ROE, where b = earnings retention rate = (1 – dividend payout ratio). Therefore, b = (1 – 0.25) = 0.75. Therefore, g = 0.75 × 7% = 5.25%.

Step 2: calculate r using CAPM, where r = RF + βi[E(RM) – RF]. Therefore, r = 3.5% + 1.6 × (9.0% – 3.5%) = 12.3%

Step 3: calculate V0 = 3.0 / (12.3% – 5.25%) = $42.55.
answerFeedback.c3793136-29c2-4ba6-890e-552ebb217b5f: Incorrect because this answer incorrectly calculates the required rate of return. Instead of applying the CAPM formula as: r = RF + βi[E(RM) – RF], the formula is incorrectly applied as: r = RF + βi[E(RM)]. That is, r = 3.5% + 1.6 × (9.0%) = 17.90%. Therefore, applying this incorrect r into the formula: V0 = D0(1 + g)/(r – g) = D1/(r – g), the candidate mistakenly arrives at: V0 = 3.1575/(17.90% – 5.25%) = $24.96, where g = b × ROE, where b = earnings retention rate = (1 – dividend payout ratio). Therefore, b = (1 – 0.25) = 0.75. Therefore, g = 0.75 × 7% = 5.25%.
answerFeedback.cc04b691-3ad8-4e5d-a525-89513afb7af7:
Correct because the intrinsic value of common stock is:

V0 = D0(1 + g)/(r – g) = D1/(r – g)

Where:

V0 = Value of a share of stock today

D1 = Expected dividend in year 1

r = Required rate of return on the stock

g = Dividend growth rate.

Step 1: calculate g, where: g = b × ROE, where b = earnings retention rate = (1 – dividend payout ratio). Therefore, b = (1 – 0.25) = 0.75. Therefore, g = 0.75 × 7% = 5.25%.

Step 2: calculate D1 = D0 × (1 + g) = $3 × (1 + 5.25%) = $3.1575

Step 3: calculate r using CAPM, where r = RF + βi[E(RM) – RF],  Therefore, r = 3.5% + 1.6 × (9.0% – 3.5%) = 12.3%

Step 4: calculate V0 = 3.1575 / (12.3% – 5.25%) = $44.79.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606083
entry.itemBody: In general, which of the following institutions most likely has a high need for liquidity and a short investment time horizon?

answerFeedback.02782cb0-531c-4d4e-85dc-16a3fd0dd05c: Incorrect because endowments have a long time horizon and low need for liquidity.
answerFeedback.45e02d47-1906-49d5-9d3b-83fc39961b3c: Incorrect because defined-benefit pension plans have a long time horizon and low need for liquidity.
answerFeedback.bbbcb35e-7245-4552-baeb-053b74b399d2: Correct because banks have a short-term horizon and high liquidity needs.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B FI 07WLP
entry.itemBody: The money duration of a bond is best defined as:

answerFeedback.11d580ff-1cd9-4b43-a9bb-4b62d44a046d: Correct because this describes the interpretation of money duration. The money duration of a bond is a measure of the price change in units of the currency in which the bond is denominated. For a given change in the annual yield-to-maturity (ΔYield), modified duration estimates the percentage price change and money duration estimates the change in currency units.
answerFeedback.711e0a3f-eb13-462f-a439-6c550b7ee505: Incorrect because this describes the calculation of the price value of a basis point (PVBP). The PVBP is an estimate of the change in the full price given a 1 bp change in the yield-to-maturity. The PVBP can be calculated using a formula similar to that for the approximate modified duration, such that: PVBP = [(PV−) − (PV+)]/2 where PV− and PV+ are the full prices calculated by decreasing and increasing the yield-to-maturity by 1 bp.
answerFeedback.8589ac0e-bfc2-4a65-bd51-10c796becd06: Incorrect because it is the annual modified duration, not Macaulay duration, times the bond’s full price. Money duration (MoneyDur) is calculated as the annual modified duration times the full price (PVFull) of the bond.

choices.itemBody: A. the bond’s Macaulay duration times the bond’s full price.
B. the estimated change in the bond’s full price in currency units for a given change in the annual yield to maturity.
C. one half of the difference in the bond’s full prices given a 1 basis point decrease and 1 basis point increase in yield-to-maturity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Alt-Hung-02
entry.itemBody: A special class of digital assets that peg their value to other financial assets through tokenization are called:

answerFeedback.6719305c-f7d3-4c0b-a181-71649a8a978c: Incorrect because security tokens digitize the ownership rights associated with publicly traded securities. On the other hand, asset-backed token maintains price parity with some target asset, the US dollar or gold, through tokenization.
answerFeedback.9adcf3e0-031b-440e-bf3f-7315a4214178: Incorrect because meme coins are cryptocurrencies often inspired by a joke and are generally launched for entertainment purposes as they gain popularity in a short period of time, which allows early purchasers to sell their holdings at an often considerable profit.
answerFeedback.9beab023-fada-425b-9efe-fd22373a37f1: Correct because a special class of digital assets is the asset-backed token, which maintains price parity with some target asset, the US dollar or gold, through tokenization.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606090
entry.itemBody: If the expected return on the market portfolio is 6% and the risk-free rate is 2%, the expected return of a security with a beta of 1.25 is closest to:

answerFeedback.438cea0a-5b86-470b-8e0c-9d1343d30763: Incorrect. It fails to subtract the risk-free rate from the market portfolio’s expected return: 2% + 1.25 × (6%) = 9.50%.
answerFeedback.60244596-bcc9-4e1f-b6e3-a58bc7ca0acc: Incorrect. It fails to add the risk-free rate: 1.25 × (6% – 2%) = 5.00%.
answerFeedback.63a93c6c-aef3-4fa6-8fe5-6cc010f791b9: Correct. The capital asset pricing model posits that the expected return of a security is E(Ri) = Rf + βi[E(Rm) – Rf] where Rf is the risk-free rate, Rm is the return on the market portfolio, and β is the beta of the security: 2% + 1.25 × (6% – 2%) = 7.00%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Ng-01
entry.itemBody: Compared to alternative investments, traditional investments are most likely characterized by:

answerFeedback.5d868f6b-0770-44b5-894b-eb029c3ed82f: Correct because alternative investments often have less regulation and less transparency than traditional investment.
answerFeedback.7dd60ac0-3914-4966-bd7f-a83678cdbe95: Incorrect because alternative investments are more likely to have greater use of leverage. Investing in alternative investments is often pursued through such special vehicles as hedge funds and private equity funds, which have flexibility to use leverage.
answerFeedback.eb337187-7c62-4149-8387-f08f5ffcf722: Incorrect because one way that alternative investments differ from traditional asset classes is that they involve more complex fee structures.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-12
entry.itemBody: A 91-day US Treasury bill with a face value of $1,000,000 has a price of $985,000. Assuming a 360-day year, the discount rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.889330b1-0924-40e5-a251-a70766928138: Incorrect because this answer transposes the Year and Days. The formula for the discount rate is DR = (Year/Days) × (FV–PV/FV). (91/360) × ((1,000,000–985,000)/1,000,000).  0.2528 × 0.015 = 0.0038 - incorrectly rounded as 3.8%.
answerFeedback.a5532a29-b994-4205-a7f9-f42c2ca2e9a0: Incorrect because this answer uses PV in the denominator rather than FV. The formula for the discount rate is DR = (Year/Days) × (FV–PV/FV). 360/91 × ((1,000,000 – 985,000) /985,000 = 3.956 × 0.01523 = 0.0602 ≈ 6.0%.
answerFeedback.be2efedc-7268-4611-ba97-9df09c3d4377: Correct because the formula for the discount rate is DR = (Year/Days) × (FV–PV/FV).  Solving the problem yields (360/91) × ((1,000,000–985,000)/1,000,000).  3.956 × 0.015 = 0.0593 or 5.93%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Teo-06
entry.itemBody: Forward rate agreements can be used by firms to:

answerFeedback.005c2d15-0c76-4f86-8f7a-e3c4c98e5b41: Correct because forward contracts in which the underlying is an interest rate are called forward rate agreements, or FRAs.
